segment.source: Typically, debugging a kernel-mode driver requires two computers.
segment.target: Typically, debugging a kernel-mode driver requires two computers.

segment.source: The debugger runs on the host computer, and the code being debugged runs on the target computer.
segment.target: The debugger runs on the host computer, and the code being debugged runs on the target computer.

segment.source: The target computer is also called the test computer.
segment.target: The target computer is also called the test computer.

segment.source: You can debug a user-mode driver on the host computer or on a separate target computer.
segment.target: You can debug a user-mode driver on the host computer or on a separate target computer.

segment.source: Before you can debug a driver running on a target computer, you must configure the target computer for debugging.
segment.target: Before you can debug a driver running on a target computer, you must configure the target computer for debugging.

segment.source: For information about configuring a target computer and setting up a debug cable, see Setting Up Kernel-Mode Debugging in Visual Studio and Provision a computer for driver deployment and testing (WDK 8.1).
segment.target: For information about configuring a target computer and setting up a debug cable, see Setting Up Kernel-Mode Debugging in Visual Studio and Provision a computer for driver deployment and testing (WDK 8.1).

segment.source: For information about using Microsoft Visual Studio to debug a driver, see Debugging Using Visual Studio.
segment.target: For information about using Microsoft Visual Studio to debug a driver, see Debugging Using Visual Studio.

segment.source: For an example of using Visual Studio to debug a kernel-mode driver, see Writing a KMDF driver based on a template.
segment.target: For an example of using Visual Studio to debug a kernel-mode driver, see Writing a KMDF driver based on a template.

segment.source: For an introduction to Debugging Tools for Windows, see Windows Debugging.
segment.target: For an introduction to Debugging Tools for Windows, see Windows Debugging.

segment.source: This video demonstrates how to use the WinDbg debugging engine directly in Visual Studio instead of running WinDbg separately.
segment.target: This video demonstrates how to use the WinDbg debugging engine directly in Visual Studio instead of running WinDbg separately.
